description:
I really like their Peking duck. It also comes in a soup as well. 

Their portions are really big , if you order 2 entrees it'll be good for 3 people. 

Pricing is reasonable as well. 

I like how they have a parking lot as well, which is very convenient.
author: Kenneth G.

description:
Been here twice and I can't say that I'm "impressed." The dumplings are sub-Par and the bao is the worst I've had. Very dry and bread-y.
Their tofu dishes are pretty legit, the rice is okay, and their more traditional Beijing dishes seem to capture the crowd that comes for them, anyhow. If you're up for an adventure, try something traditional. 

They do serve your typical American Chinese food, for sure. That seems pretty standard from what I could see. The flavors aren't bland but there are some things that are hit-or-miss. Some things they make better than others and in some dishes--better just not make it at all.

Vegetables are fine and flavorful. I had the pea sprouts with garlic. I've had all the dumplings on the menu, nothing to rave about, honestly. Definitely not their speciality, here. You can tell, no offense to my Chinese Grandma working day-in-and-day-out back in the kitchen. 

The soup is pretty whatever. Not bland, flavorful, and will hit-the-spot if you need a hangover pick-me-up or feel like being all warm and cozy in the inside. Except, they use the same broth basically for all the soup and there is fake crab meat and fish balls of some kind. If you're not into that, don't order the soup. You'll be maybe upset if you're all about getting the real thing all the time.

Not the number #1 best Chinese but definitely more flavorful than others I've been to have to offer in the area. If you haven't tried Shanghai Dumpling King nearby, try it. It's killer-deliciously-fantastic. They specialize obviously, with dumplings. They were closed today, so I came to Beijing. Beijing will do the trick if you're feeling like a lazy bag of beans on your way home from bart or the freeway. They've got parking if you need it. 

Just don't order the dumplings. Please, don't.
author: T. C.

description:
It's a small spot but famous for Chinese.  
I love Fried rice here.
The service depends on stuffs , some fast and good but some slow and not care much. 
I ordered the tender in spicy soup for try like the recommended,  omg!!  A lot of fried chilies on top of the soup. I dont know it's normal or not but really waste of it because not many people eat it.
author: Tirintorn C.

description: Yangxiezi pot have no lamb but full of pig foot!!!!! I will never go to this restaurant again!
author: Di W.

description: I've tried the Chow Mein and it was greasy af. Then they don't bother to clean outside the restaurant, their was a bunch of dog poop on the side walk next to the restaurant and they left it their until the rain washed it away. And I also get a horrible smell when I walk near the back. They surprisingly get a lot of costumers and that means they make a lot of money right? Well the restaurant hasn't been fixed a bunch of wild plants are growing on the side, the sign has faded writing. With the money they make they should use it to fix up the restaurant. I have stopped going here because it's disgusting, this restaurant is really close to my house but I rather go to the other restaurant that's 30 minutes away:
author: Noe L.

description:
I tried the food from Beijing Restaurant at SF street food festival. I was happy to see Chinese food in SF street food festival, but not until I tried them. The quality of the food they offered in the festival is far below par.

Two dishes offered in 2017 festival, street pancake and sizzling squid.

The sizzling squid is served super fast, taste is not impressive, but ok. A little bit overly salty, but still acceptable.

I waited very long time for the pancake, even there's not too many people in the line. 

Once got the pancake, I quickly noticed it looks completely different from what it showed on menu photo. The photo showed pancake has egg on the outside, with glaze of cilantro and green onions. But what I get is a light browned pancake have nothing outside, no egg, no greens.
And the pancake taste weird. The pancake part taste very similar to traditional American pancake, instead of Chinese pancake. The filling is not tasty too, the sauce used in the pancake filling is the same as the sauce used for squid I believe, which is not what I expected from a Chinese pancake.
author: Wenjing Y.

description:
This place was decent.  Reasonably good food (some dishes were better than others), mediocre service, and a simple, clean setting.

My husband and I shared the following, and had plenty of leftovers to take home:

1) String beans - quite good!
2) Beef pancake - good, but didn't live up to the hype
3) Cumin lamb - pretty good
4) Chicken chow mein - standard, but fine 

The food came out fairly quickly, but our waitress forgot about us after that.  We had to flag her down later to ask for our check and to go boxes for our leftovers.

The setting was simple and reasonably clean.

Overall, a decent Chinese spot - we would definitely come back.
author: Barnali D.

description:
The outside of this restaurant is a pig stye!  They take no pride in maintaining the front and exterior.  It's dusty & dirty and in need of paint. 
There is a side area with steps that is unsightly and dirty looking, with white buckets on each step.  There are piles of cardboard & boxes laying around along side of the building with a black mop leaning against it.  Employees often stand out there and smoke.  Who would patronize a restaurant with a filthy exterior?  Who knows what their kitchen looks like.  Ugh! not for me!
author: Anuhe'a K.

description:
But FIVE STAR for Chili Delight.  I like heat and this is very hot, but it's great to take home and use to mix into scrambled eggs, or rice, or ramen noodles even. Maybe go fusion and include it in a lasagna, or over a baked potato.
There is good flavor in that heat but I do prefer to use it as a flavoring.

Also, they have a tiny parking lot.
author: Jane W.

description: This place is filthy. Unmaintained, table is not clean properly. Dishes are so so. Over rated!
author: Michael C.

description:
I'll admit - the Yao Ming pictures definitely drew me into checking out this place but I'm glad I did because it's a pretty legit spot. The best part - they have their own small private lot to the side for customer parking! - that's unheard of in SF.

The menu is pretty extensive - stews, veggies, appetizers, cold dishes, beijing pancakes, and even hotpot. The veggie fried rice was ok - great portions but the flavor was avg. I was actually surprised they had rice because northern chinese cuisine is known for not eating rice and supplementing it with bing and baos (pancakes and buns). 

The fish fillet with tofu was good - slightly oily but the flavors were great. The best dish was the bean curd and napa cabbage warm pot / soup - great flavors but not heavy. I wish the bean curd was actually bean curd and not tofu - either that or change the menu item name. 

The Beijing street pancake was awesome - as close to authentic as you can get. Thin layer of egg around a pancake filled with crispy wonton skin chips, hoisin sauce, and cilantro. Yum!

Prices are good and they take credit card. The actual restaurant isn't all that big so if you have a large party - might want to call to be sure they have enough seating.
author: Brenda L.

description:
I normally have liked this place since going here more then 5yrs. ago, today I ordered delivery on Eat24 app & they forgot to include some chili sauce & Chinese black vinegar I had asked for!
Oh well!
I recommend the cumin lamb, any of the filled pancakes, the beef noodle soups & the Beijing specialties!
Great prices for the amount of food you get!
author: Dan S.

description: Ordered two order dumplings delivery, cabbage pork and three favor. I was totally cold when I get them. And some of the dumplings taste weird. I'm Chinese, I know how dumpling taste like. Disappointing!
author: Foodieeee H.

description:
Had a horrible experience with their delivery boy.

My roommate ordered food through Eat24 and after 20mins or so I hear the loudest bangs from my front gate. 

This Chinese kid literally banged on the front door gate so hard, my neighbor came out thinking someone was trying to break in. He thought he was the DEA or something I swear lol.

Told this kid to chill down but of course he didn't understand me. So I got my food from him and gave him 2$ for tips. (Food total was ~14$) 

This kid had the nerve to mumble in Chinese and suck his teeth like a little kid and slam my door. 

At this point, I had to tell this ungrateful motherfuxker to calm down and if he wants to throw it down we can. But of course he didn't understand me and drove off.

Food was great and it came on time though on the positive note. This delivery boy just needs to learn to be humble and respectful. 

2$ for 14$ is more than enough in my eye considering there was nothing hard about this delivery to a house. Even if it was 0$ you don't slam people's 

***
Didn't realize the FDA posted a warning on their yelp page stating they got a safety rating in the bottom 5% locally.... will never order from here.
author: Kent K.

description:
More of three and half stars. 

First of all, the atmosphere was quite authentic northern China. From the traditional Chinese cutout artwork to the loud tv shows, good or bad, it reminded me of how it's like where I'm from. 

The appetizer, house special boiled sliced pork shoulder, was incredible. The taste, texture and presentation were all spot on. 5/5. 

The Zha Jiang Noodle, which was the main reason why I came for, wasn't as impressive. Though looked authentic, the noodle was a bit on the tough side. There was enough sauce that came with it. Also the sauce didn't taste that fresh for some reason. 3/5.

Overall, just ok. Might visit again for some other dishes.
author: Morpheus F.

description:
FIVE STARS PURELY FOR THE BEAN CURD GLASS NOODLE DISH WITH BEEF. I AM HEAVILY ADDICTED TO THESE NOODLES AND SOMETIMES EVEN DREAM OF THEM. 
For a Chinese restaurant, the servers are actually pretty nice. They're a little clueless at times, but they smile when I order which I appreciate. Seems like a family run restaurant. You can often see the grandpa sitting at a chair near the register enjoying his restaurant while the younger family members are trying to organize everything. Please never close down Beijing Restaurant or I will have to embark on an endless journey to fulfill my cravings for your delicious noodles. UUUUGGGGGGUUUU, this noodle dish is seriously unlike anything I've ever eaten. The texture of the noodles are chewy and long and oh so flavorful! The beef can seem a little undercooked at times to be completely honest, but ain't nothing beats them nooooods. I brought some home to my big sister and she's in love too. 
Parking is in the back of the restaurant. It's really nice that a shop in SF actually has parking for their customers.
author: Kim N.

description: Ordered from here for delivery and it was awesome! Came super quick, was inexpensive, and super delicious. My kung pao shrimp was really flavorful. Would definitely order from here again.
author: Anastasia S.

description: Horrible waitress who working Aug 2nd at 11am. I placed an lunch order at 11:20, and eat 24 messaged me the order is gonna be ready until 12:10pm. I called the restaurant and asked how long it's gonna take. She said after 30mins. I was wondering why it's take so long? Usually when I place an order it takes about 10-20 mins. She started giving me attitude, guess what?  Why can't I go to other places?
author: Jin C.

description: LOVE IT the waiters are really friendly, the food is excellent me and my family go at least once a week we love it their you should try it you don't need reservations but bring your stomach!!!
author: Esther M.

description: I love their dumplings so much, and they are not expensive! My favorite dumplings spot. Their spicy beef tripe also taste very good, It's definitely worth trying.
author: Angelala L.

description: I have been order delivery here for so many times! I feel really disappointed on this time! Corn nuts is not fresh! I can see it through the color of the onion, and the corn tastes so sour like the overnight food(or even pass 2days! I don't eat overnight food at home at all! How come a restaurant would prove customer overnight food? What is the reason to eat at restaurant for giving customer overnight food? And that's my favorite corn nut! Unacceptable! And the problem happens so many time is they always forget to give me straw when I order the Beijing yogurt.  Never come back! Fk off!
author: Rainy G.

description: The food is good, the service is adequate and it's super convenient.  I'd go back.  I understand they are under new management in the past couple of years, 'cause 10 years or so ago it wasn't that good. I don't understand their low Health Dept. score, but then again I haven't seen the kitchen!
author: Marvelous Margaret M.

description: I paid tips through yelp（Eat 24）for delivery. The delivery guy yell at me for not giving him tips.
author: Chang L.

description:
General chicken was soggy and the sauce was gross, tasted like they covered it in ketchup. The pancake was good but also soggy. 

Wasted 20 bucks !
author: Mariah S.

description:
I wish that there was an option for "No STAR". 
Terrible food and service. 

Please don't come to this place. It will only leave you with disappointment and unsatisfactory. 

Food is way below average. 

1. I had the Combination Chow Mian(with beef, chicken, and pawn). There are 4 pieces of pawn, 3 pieces of chicken, and less than 5 pieces of beef. Chinese onion is much more than bean sprouts, and Chinese onion and bean sprouts are the only vege. 

2. One of the the beef pieces is uncooked. Half of this piece is red. 

Service is horrible.

1. Long time after I placed order, the young female waitress didn't serve tea/water until I asked for tea. 

2. I requested for replacement of my Chow Mian after I found the uncooked beef. However, the chief insisted that it was cooked. (what a BS). Finally I received my new serving of Chow Mian. Guess what? There was only beef. Chicken and pawn were all gone. I ordered a freaking COMBINATION Chow Mian. 
     COMBINATION!!!         COMBINATION!!! 
The female waitress gave me a spoon rather than chopsticks. WHAT THE HELL? Noodle with spoon? It took her for ever to give me a pair of chopsticks. 

3. It took the waitress forever to give back my change. They received my money, started to do other things, and they forgot to give back my change. WTF??? 

What a sh*t hole place with sh*t show.
author: Yukai K.

description: I was disappointed the food was not very good, I've order before from here, and it was good , the food tasted like it was reheated
author: C J.

description:
First time used online delivery and we had a very very bad experience with their driver.

Driver won't deliver the food inside to our business due to not enough tips?

Wow I don't think we will ever order from this place again unless they change their bad attitude driver!

If you want tips you better earn it. 

Service first before tips not the other way around!!! 


We were going to give this guy $10 tips in cash but his attitude receive $0
author: Mack A.

description:
I liked that they updated their menu to include pictures of almost all the dishes; great for people who can't read chinese or who aren't familiar with the mainlain chinese dishes. I was really hoping to order the fried potato tower, which I saw a photo of on Yelp many years ago, but I didn't see it on the menu :(

The beijing duck for $40 was just okay. Nothing really extraordinary or out of this world. You have to order in advance to get the duck. I'd encourage you to visit Great China in Berkeley for really unique beijing duck; no need to order in advance. The duck at Beijing restaurant was moderately fatty and the skin was somewhat crispy but there were also pieces that were soggy. It didn't feel like we got much meat or skin for the price we paid; must have been a really small duck. It was nice that it came with soup for the price though; not all places give you the bones in a soup. 

The beijing street pancake was okay, but nothing like what you can get on the streets of beijing. I wish they included the crispy wonton inside. It's hard to find this dish regardless though, so I'm glad they gave it an attempt. 

Crispy eggplant dish was different and pretty tasty. I'd never had anything like that before, but it would taste just like you would expect battered and fried eggplant with sauce to taste like. 

The chive pancake was okay, but I've had better -- crispier and firmer on the outside. 

Sauteed pea shoots were the bomb! I'm glad we reminded them of our order, because they almost forgot. If you need a vegetable dish, get the pea shoots if they're in season!
author: Audrey L.

description: I come here a lot. One of my favorite in the area. Some dishes are very good, like clear noodles, fish soup, chive dumpling.
author: J o.

description:
So I stopped writing Yelp reviews a while ago. I had to get on here to review this joke of a shop.

This is supposed to be a cheap Chinese food place that gets mostly funded by take out orders.

What a joke! Hahaha 9 dollars for noodles and 12 dollars for shredded pork. Ok those prices are about right, seriously they are actually pretty good. Ok let's look at the pictures. 4 soupfuls of sauce for the noodles literally 1/4 of the smallest plastic container they could find. 1/6 of a take out box of pork.

I would rather go eat my own sh it than come back to this place.

How am I even supposed to eat my noodles with no sauce. Jesus how am I going to sleep tonight.

Oh the meat pancakes actually tasted pretty good.
author: Jason T.

description:
I only had the Jianbing, or Beijing street pancakes, to go here, but I have to say, that these are the most authentic I've tasted yet outside of Beijing. It tastes much better than "Bing of Fire" in Seattle and "Mr. Bing" in NYC / HK. 

The item is off menu, so be sure to ask for it!
author: Cynthia X.

description: My home taste Chinese food. The right portion and the right taste and the right price. I can't get away from this store. My favorite is vegetable fried rice.
author: Shar L.

description: Don't order from this restaurant unless you want to be irritated beyond belief after you drive home and are missing items you paid $65 for!  Two times in a row this has happened to my family and me so we will never order from here again.
author: Kristin T.

description: How is this Chinese food? This shit is like a crap remake of panda Express...........................
author: Derek W.

description: I was born in Beijing and had lived in that city till 21. I find this restaurant very authentic. Do try 炒肝 if you like that. 京东肉饼 is also not bad.
author: Yuzhang H.

description:
Great food, easy online ordering, timely delivery.
Will have to visit the restaurant  soon!
author: Joseph T.

description:
So the food is good here, but I just had the worse experience ever.  The deliver guy driving his fancy white Mercedes just gave me the finger from his car because he wanted a bigger tip.  So as if that wasn't bad enough he did it with my 2 year old son looking out the window at him   WTF?  

This guy should be fired!
author: C W.

description:
If I could give 0 stars I would , I ordered food today from here it was horrible . I said no onion in my food yet they put so much ! And I ordered chicken fried rice and chowmien nothing had chicken only
Like 3-4 pieces of chicken the rest was noodles onions and rice . At least they gave me back my money .
author: Wendy M.

description: I've been here many times and the waitress today was horrible. I ordered my noodle shop and an order of dumplings. She brings me my order without the proper utensils. I ask here for the utensils and she goes off and does whatever she is doing. Since I am emailing my clients i am not in a rush to eat.  I look up and  she is serving the other customers and you know what she brings them everything they need. I say hey miss where are my untensils? There are three other group of mandarin speakers that came after me was served first. I am not a mandarin speaker and i said hey how long does it take for you to bring me what I need to eat? The owner looks and me and tells me so sorry. wtf. The food has always been good but jesus christ if you dont know how to be a waitress please learn. They all acted like they speak english but they dont remember i've been here many times over the past years. Her excuse for not bringing me what I need, she said she rang out of spoons and bowls....... 8 people in the restaurant.
author: Dennis K.

description: Consistently satisfactory food and service. Authentic Beijing cuisine. Great for people tired of American Chinese food.
author: Yi F.

description: Tried two dishes, steam buns and meatball, and neither tasted good. Buns had too much skins, and meatball was too salty. Won't come back.
author: Bella H.

description:
Really conflicted on my review here. Their food is definitely great, and not your average Chinese food. I have no idea if it is authentic, but I'm assuming it must be from a particular region (Beijing?).

But their service has been horrendously bad and I've felt very unwelcome both times we ate in this restaurant. It seemed to be a combination of incompetence and something else. Other tables seemed to get better service.

I had to constantly get up to ask for things from our server (water, the check, etc). And it was probably the first time I've ever left a $0 tip. I definitely won't be eating in again, and MIGHT consider it for delivery, as they DO have very unique and delicious food.
author: Rocco B.

description: I chose this restaurant is a favorite of my husband. While moving, but we will be back here. The restaurant food was good，However, services and sanitation shall be increased.
author: Xin H.

description:
This is the only place in town that I go to for Peking Duck.  The pickings are limited, I will admit, but this place is the best of the 6 or 7 odd places I've tried including HK lounge and others.  For one they are one of the only places that serves the duck with flat bing/pancakes, not the mantou pockets--  that is not PK duck guys!!

They have a good selection of Beijing dishes, and all the local stuff, like lu da gun, etc.  it's really worth trying :)
author: Alice S.

description:
Ordered delivery. One of dishes was the house special shredded pork which is shown with noodles in the photos. I ordered that and noted with noodles. They call to tell me it's not with noodles and it's a pancake??? So I asked if we can change it and their reply? No. So why the f did you call me for?? The fried chicken wings taste like purse salt, gross. Eggplant was super oily and the shredded pork was pathetic and NOT a pancake, it's a wrap. 

Will never eat here again.
author: A W.

description: Very disappointing. Not very authentic Northern Chinese food. The jian bing guo zi was very disappointing. The pickled napa cabbage was okay... could've been more flavorful. Waiter was super rude -- rolled his eyes at me several times, gave cheeky remarks to every single table. Won't be coming back here.
author: Sherry L.

description:
The outside of the building scared me a little - Old, dirty , falling apart, surrounded by an old chain link fence. Inside however was clean and well decorated. Service friendly. Food was really awesome. They even have parking - how rare is that in SF???  
Highly recommend.
author: B K.

description:
The food has gotten a bit spicier here, and well done. I love their beef stew with la mien (hand-pulled noodles). It's a generous noodle serving, chewy and filling. The beef is a bit grainy, but tasty. I had a taste of my friend's asparagus fish and it was very clean tasting and the fish was tender, also a bit spicy.

Service was friendly and helpful.

While I'm nervous about that health score - which I just saw because I came back to review - I've never gotten sick from eating there.
author: Charles B.

description:
This restaurant has been a fixture in the Excelsior District and has been a mystery to me for years, at least until now. Beijing is known as the little red Resturant that specializes in norther Chinese dishes. Even Yao Ming (the Houston Rockets basketball legend) loved this place and has been on record as saying "it's one of his favorite places to eat when he comes to San Francisco."

Each dish is packed with big flavors and the menu itself, offers so many options to choose from. In fact the current menu has about eight pages worth of delicious food. I personally loved the: long beans, a curry style chow mein, the crispy onion pancake and of course the steamed pork dumplings. The long beans were fried just right and the pepper sauce that's coated on those beans takes the dish to new heights. The curry version of chow mein uses angel hair noodles and mixed with large pieces of shrimp, green onions and dollops of Curry. Add eggs and cuts of sausage, that's married together in spices. 

The onion cake was cooked to perfection. Unlike most places that keep it drenched in cooking oil. It was the best combination of airy and crispy and cooked to perfection. Although it was good it missed a salty element like hoisin sauce to compliment it. Instead of getting it, Thats when the frustration began to set in. Our table had continuously asked for hoisin sauce or something to use as a dipping sauce. We were told numerous times they were getting it for us. But fifteen minutes later and after asking the staff members numerous times. we were finally told they don't carry any. That kinda served was the theme throughout the meal. Plates of food were slammed down on our dining table. When we were giving our order, the waiter was real short and seemed annoyed. Like we did something wrong by wanting to eat there. Asking for things like hoisin and water was a chore and became frustrating. 

Now I will say it could've been because it was busy. Because when I asked why was it like that. it was made clear the main focus should always be on the foods an not the service. So the service is just secondary I guess. Anyhow I say that as a warning so people aren't turned off by it. So once again the Restuarant is very small so you will feel like people are sitting and eating right on top of you. There's very little you can do about it But the food was really good and the price point was low. That ultimately means it's worth going back for another taste in my opinion.
author: Donald W.

description:
Hmm. Originally gave 5 stars, but this place messed up 2 parts of my orders the last two times.

They also skimped on the meat a lot. Delivery is fast and workers are nice, but quality is getting worse :(
author: Ellie M.

description:
Brought my parents here for dinner one night because they were sick of all the fancy Michelin star stuff I'd been feeding them (first world asian people problems).

Chose Beijing Restaurant because of the whole Yao-Ming-has-been-here deal and the good reviews. I think Yao Ming might've come here hungover.

Service:
-It was okay and cordial, did what was asked but nothing more, typical of asian restaurants' concept of "service"

Food:
-Fried lamb skewers, a signature order here but it was just decent, maybe 6.5/10 compared to typical lamb skewers you find on dirty chinese streets
-Beijing street pancake, looked super authentic and I had high hopes for it especially from the waiter's recommendation, unfortunately this tasted terrible and I didn't understand the cheap wonton crisps in there
-Beijing style noodles with brown sauce, house special three flavored vegetables, house special shredded pork with braised sauce, these all tasted more or less the same to me after a while, which screams non-authentic-americanized-chinese-food

No, my parents didn't enjoy this either. Should've brought them to an asian buffet instead because at least the mediocre food there are of better value, and asian parents love value.
author: Tian Q.

description: Really great fresh tasting Chinese food in the city. The food is flavorful and the portions are great as well. My favorite are the cashew chicken, basically all the chicken dishes and their noodles. Most chinese restaurants I've been to taste like they made they're food half ass. Beijing has very good authentic tasting food. I wish the customer service was a little nicer and would like servers to check in to see if we want to order. Last time I felt like they purposely ignored me after seating.
author: Francois D.

description:
Quite disappointing.
I stopped in and placed a carry out order as I wanted some Won Ton Soup. On a whim I added a few more items to the order including Fried Prawn and Sautéed Green Beans.
The man who took my order was pleasant but during my wait I witnessed him bussing tables and PICKING THINGS OFF OF THE FLOOR then delivering food to tables and handling fresh table settings without washing his hands in between.
He and then someone I assumed was a delivery driver both put my bag together constantly fiddling with it. For some reason the only used one tall bag placing the soup containers at the bottom.
When I got home and removed the items and was not happy:
The bottom of the bag was completely flooded by one of the soup containers that had leaked and lost all of its liquid. So I had to deal with the mess of wet napkins and fishing the chili sauce containers out while dumping the bag of broth down the sink. If you order soup to go or delivery here, I strongly recommend you insist that they put it in a separate bag so it can be monitored easier in travel.
At least have lost the broth I now had extra Won Tons to add to the second soup container to make a better dumpling/soup ratio (I was feeling Melissa McCarthy's struggle in Ghostbusters). 
The broth was very bland and definitely needed the Chili Sauce to give it some flavor.
I was shocked to find the Fried Prawn was whole and with eyes and feelers poking out through breading. In an attempt to be adventurous I tried one but it was quiet disgusting to me and tasted like their digestive tracks were still intact and they had been fried in old oil. Perhaps this is a more traditional Chinese way to serve them? I don't know. I had never seen them prepared this way and was not expecting it but has now made me leery of ordering fried prawn in restaurants without asking if they'd been cleaned. At any rate, the oil they used was inexcusable.
I'll attempt to attach a pic of the prawn so you can see what I mean.
Lastly, where the soup was bland, the Sautéed Green Beans were almost too salty but still pleasant.
I can't recommend this place to anyone but if you insist on going, take these things into consideration.
author: Ken H.

description: Great food here last night.  Cold sliced beef was delicious.  The cumin lamb-tasty.  Pork with veg warm pot was great.  The dumplings are average and the pork with ground bean sheet and bean sprouts was garlicky and delicious but hard to eat with the long slippery noodles.  Next time I'll ask for a scissors!  The place is clean and inviting and was noisy with happy eaters.  Our food came quickly.  Service was fine and attentive.  Oh!  and parking is easy in the lot behind the resto.
author: Karen L.

description:
I wasn't terribly impressed. My mom is from Beijing and she's fairly in to this Northern Chinese stuff and we split some marinated cucumbers, a jelly noodle chicken thing, some pork loin, and the funky spicy meatballs. I can't saw I was terribly impressed by any of it.

The attitude is pretty authentic though. The staff is pretty argumentative, but not really in a bad way.
author: Misha T.

description: Depends on what you order. Some of the dishes were pretty good but others were average and not authentic.
author: Simon Z.

description:
I feel obligated to give a justified review as a "Beijinger" for 20 years before I came to the US. I went last Sunday with some family friends who just got off plane from Beijing for a trip in the US. We were warmly greeted by the staff as well as the homey decorations. Mumu, the owner brought all the Chinese folk arts like paintings, "jian zhi" from Beijing and I felt like I just stepped in a magic door back to a local restaurant in Beijing.

As for the food, everything is authentic Chinese. And my favorite was "jiu cai he zi" (green oion pan cakes?) A friend was have a toothache at that time so we ordered only soft, less flavorful dishes, but I am looking forward to some spicy food next time. The only improvement I would suggest is that using potatoes, green peppers and eggplants for "di san xian" since that is the authentic way. 

For a perfect ending, make sure to try their authentic Beijing desserts like "lu da gun", "ai wo wo", "wan dou huang" and thank me later:)
author: Siruo Z.

description: EXCELLENT food, just a bit on the oily side. my only complaint is that the service was a little less than satisfactory
author: Sam S.

description: I am not sure if their in store cuisine quality differentiates from their delivery service but something needs to be said.... I don't usually leave bad reviews for restaurants even when the food is sub par...but when the service sucks as well it is another story indeed. If you like getting mediocre food and being told your tip isn't good enough while somebody holds their hand out asking for more choose this restaurant and it will surely cheer you up. However I didn't enjoy their behavior or their what ever tasting food. I will not be going back
author: Fan W.

description:
Honestly the WORST experience ever. And I'm so sorry to have to say that. I ordered food tonight and just had the WORST EXPERIENCE. I have never experienced such RUDE behavior in my life. 
First of all it was an order for delivery. The driver eventually called to say he was outside... I ended up standing outside for almost 20 minutes wondering where he was. I called his phone back at least 10 times, (AND I PROMISE IM NOT EXAGGERATING), only for him to keep hanging up on me. I called the restaurant 5 times in the middle of all of it to help the lady on the phone try to direct the driver to no avail. When he finally found my house, he handed me my food and had me sign the receipt. I left $0 tip just because the whole ordeal was a mess, and for the fact that he had me standing in the cold for 20 minutes and kept ignoring my calls and/or hanging up on me.
When he saw the $0 tip amount he snatched the food out of my hand and DEMANDED that I give him a tip.
I explained why I didn't want to and that I was not obligated to. He even called the restaurant and yelled at his coworker trying to force her to tell me that I have to leave a tip.

I told him to take the food back and cancel my order. 

Because of him, I will NEVER go back or order from again.
author: ethena c.

description:
The Peking Duck is amazing. They can run out of it pretty quickly so make sure you get there and order before you find a table. 

Very authentic northern Chinese cuisine. We ordered around 10 different dishes and they were all so delicious. Highlights would be the dumplings, boiled fish, and shredded pork. 

It is far out but totally worth the trip for the duck alone.
author: Laura D.

description: Food is good but delivery guy was a jerk! He demanded a tip and told me to pick up my own food when I didn't give it to him.
author: Tameka M.

description:
Delicious food
Fast service
Reasonable price
Just finished eating there with friends and already thinking to bring my family here to try.
author: Sharon L.

description:
My office catered lunch from here, and I was sorely disappointed with the food.

- Sesame chicken was cold. It wasnt even mildly warm, it was cold. 

- Kung pao tofu was too salty.

- Vegetable fried rice was decent. Not too oily, but it'd be sad if you screw up fried rice too.

One of the worst Chinese food I've had :(
author: Christina N.

description: Awesome, delicious local outlet that's unassuming falling apart rotting wood mess on the outside which says nothing about the shiny brand new-looking spacious interior which is like a totally different restaurant. The food is the best part, I ordered the corn shower, pork belly in soy, and seasonal vegetables (don't know the English translation for it) all of which was superb for a very fair price, too. A tinse salty is the primary complaint. Parking lot has 6 spaces which fill quickly. Service is fast & friendly.
author: Richard C.

description:
Visiting the city and our friends again. This was suggested to us by our friend. I guess he was craving Chinese food. That's ok with me as long as it's not Panda Express. What's amazing about this place is that there is a parking lot. OMG yes you read that right! Hallelujah! Get here early though since it usually fills up fast. 

Did you know Yao Ming eats here? 

Staff is pretty funny and friendly. The menu features feel good home cooked meal items. Get the lamb skewers!! I liked the chive pancake. That was yummy. They have some interesting variations on the classics though. Like honey pine nut shrimp. What?? 

Yao Ming eats here. 

This place is pretty close to hubs' grandparents so we'll probably eat here again when we're visiting family.
author: Cindy K.

description: If I could give zero stars I would. Just came back and I am now on my porcelain goddess throne unloading everything I ate from this awful restaurant (TMI, I know, but dammit!).  They cooked bad meat and over seasoned it to mask the taste in their spicy beef and bean curb house entree.  They stuff bad pork inside their signature eggplant dish (meat was red and tasted sour).  They didn't serve our garlic pea sprouts until after they gave us our check and it was lacking of flavor and GARLIC! But we knew our meal was going to be great when they served us our first dish which was suppose to be hot and sour soup but it was instead a garlic sauce of some type, which the server actually served on two separate soup bowls expecting us to eat it. HORRIBLE. Maybe Yao Ming should visit this place again to give them back their good food mojo.  We barely put a dent on any of our dishes! Our check was 47.69 and we still included 15% tip (yea, I know.smh)! :*( Beijing Restaurant: 1 Sick Customer: 0. They win.
author: Angela S.

description:
Been to this place 5 times! 
Awesome duck! Half for warping with onions and hoisin sauces, another half for duck soup! 
"Jianbing guozi", best I ever had in the US!
Also authentic decoration of Beijing style!
Will come back again and again!
author: Wei Z.

description:
This place looks like a dirty little shack on the outside. But don't let that deceive you. They have authentic BeiJing style dishes you don't commonly see in restaurants.

We ordered the Beijing street pancake, which was ok I would give it a 3. I've never tried it before and it was recommended on yelp. But it was a bit salty for my taste. The Chinese burger was real good though, a must try. We also got the cumin lamb. Real flavorful with a little kick.

I definitely want to come back to get their green onion pancake and their hand pulled noodles. 

They have a small lot for parking too. A nice plus. Service was mediocre, usual for a Chinese restaurant.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
If it's good enough for Yao Ming, it's good enough for me!  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8sTqr9ehaZuqORQCddYeUg?select=vI5g8afp5s7yUUFE9_yGKA)

Divey outside, pretty clean and modern for a Chinese dive inside. I like how they have pics of neighborhood peeps dining here on their walls. Came here for lunch with some coworkers. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8sTqr9ehaZuqORQCddYeUg?select=_UF0hGLj9wTyhSLRC5TeYg) 

Since I'm no Chinese food expert, ordered Beijing Resto's signature dishes according to Yelp friends Lolia S, Wilhelm Y, and Ken K

#89 ($8) BEEF STEW NOODLE SOUP --  My favorite. A little different since I'm used to the Taiwanese beef noodle soup but the noodles were delicious with nice elasticity. Great flavor on the broth, not as deep as I've had but the super tender beef stew pieces make the dish. I want a whole bowl to myself. Order this! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8sTqr9ehaZuqORQCddYeUg?select=kZjK5PkP_RdZj9wxtPx1cA)

#31 ($10) CUMIN LAMB -- Dry fried style, great cumin spice, tender. Perfect with rice. Order this!  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8sTqr9ehaZuqORQCddYeUg?select=lATKkhI1y63X9uP4PjCkQg)

#55 ($8) BEEF PANCAKE - Mexican folks speakin' Chinese! Tasted like a Chinese ground beef quesadilla. It went ok with the table chili sauce, it would be better with guac, sour cream, and Cholula! Try it, you might like it.   (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8sTqr9ehaZuqORQCddYeUg?select=nZblTr6wA3DPXJnE5XE2yw)

#46 ($10) HOT BRAISED BEEF TENDON - w/bok choy. Sticky, tender, but chewy. Could have been stewed more. Great flavors though. You can skip. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/8sTqr9ehaZuqORQCddYeUg?select=i2aM6pE4dbEqiDMbPY2rqg)  


Another popular item here is the $5.50 lunch special, you get a soup and one of those typical Chinese-American rice plates. It was very popular with the Non-Chinese crowd and I'm sure it's OK. Do yourself a favor, skip it and order what they're known for, Beijing specialty dishes.
author: Earl G.

description:
The food here is good and pretty authentic. It's supposed to also be Yao Ming's favorite when he comes to SF. If Yao thinks it's good, it MUST be good :)

We got the dumplings, lamb with cumin and tofu with mushroom. The service was efficient and friendly.

The dumplings were amazing! Lots of juice and chewy wrap. You can tell the dumplings were handmade at the restaurant. TOTALLY WORTH IT!

You can't screw up lamb with cumin. It's a northern Chinese staple and this one was no different. 

The tofu was also very tasty. 

I'll definitely try some other more authentic Beijing dishes on my visits.
author: Michael J.

description:
So far so good!
I highly recommend the BJ street style pancakes, it's good enough to get two orders.. Pretty similar to the the famous street food I grew up with in Beijing.

Just wish they have the cumin lamb kebabs.. Bring those back!!!
author: Jackie G.

description: I ordered a Veg/Pork Noodles soup.. I was really disappointed compared to the last few times I went there. Noodles were barely boiled not the mention pork which I'm not even sure that it was pork, strange taste and texture. A total lack of vegetables and the broth was just ok.. It doesn't worth the price..
author: Océane M.

description:
Came in here 2 days ago with my friends.There is a small parking lot next to it where you can park your car. The place isn't very big, but we went during the day and it wasn't packed so it was fine. 

We ordered 5 dishes for the 3 of us and it was plenty. 

Sauteed String Beans:
There was nothing special about this plate. 

Green Onion Pancake:
This is actually my first time eating a thick green onion pancake. It tastes pretty good, maybe there were too much dough that the taste of green onion was quite lacking. It would have been better if it was more flavorful. one thing good about this is that it's not oily like other pancakes I've had.

Beef Stew Noodle Soup:
It tastes okay, it was a little spicy but very slightly. I like everything about this from the thick chewy noodles to the beef, but the soup was a bit bland for my liking, I've definitely had better beef stew noodle in the city. 

Chives and Shrimp dumpling:
The dumpling tasted fine, it wasn't anything special. I don't think it was worth my money for the dumplings because I think the ones I buy at ranch 99 tastes better but that's just me.

I don't remember what this dish is called so I'm just gonna name it the 
5 color noodle salad:
It consist of cucumbers, green and red bell peppers, egg, cilantro and noodles. It's a cold dish. They first bring it out and set up and placed nicely on a plate with the noodles in the middle, then they pour a brown thick soup with pork shreds in it, and starts mixing it all together. The texture of the noodle is actually very interesting because it looks like "Ho Fun" (Thick rice noodle) but when you bite it the texture tastes kind of like jello. I think it tastes okay, but I'm not a fan. Even though they mix it in the sauce it seems that the flavor of the sauce can't really seep into the food therefore you can't really taste it.

For me I think the food here was all lacking in flavor which was disappointing because in the Chinese culture the flavors are suppose to be very bold and strong. All in all I don't think I'm a fan, but it may be too soon to judge because I haven't tried the other foods on the menu.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Food= good.  I love their spicy dishes!! 

Dim sum items = okay.

Service= OK. 

Prices= reasonable.

I use EAT24, so I've yet to step inside this place.  I drive past it several times a week... there's a small parking lot.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Decided to try to this because I thought they would serve porridge, but they actually don't. I was sick during the time I came here so the chicken corn soup was my favorite of all the stuff I ordered. The soup was clear, refreshing and loaded with sweet corn. Definitely something to soothe a dry throat. The Cumin Beef looked like beef jerky and kind of tasted like it too. It was pretty chewy and hard to bite into. The egg pancake thing (forgot what it's called) was okay. I expected more of a scrambled egg taste, but it tasted more like a flour pancake mix. 

Waiting to get our check ruined my experience. We waited forever and had to ask them twice when we were seated right in front of the register. What made me more annoyed was when the table next to us ask for their check way after we did, they got theirs right away and we still didn't get ours. 

Other than that the guy who was serving pretty much everyone was very entertaining. He knows how to talk to people even though his English isn't that great and it was pretty funny just listening to how he interacted with other people. 

All in all, it's a good place for authentic Beijing food, but expect iffy customer service.
author: Renee Y.

description:
Great food, variety of Northern Chinese dishes not commonly carried at other Chinese restaurants. 

Really enjoyed spicy beef stew noodle soup, the beef cold cuts, and the combination stir-fried vegetables. The noodles were al dente, broth had a nice kick and a bit of Sichuan peppercorn taste without being too spicy. The cold cuts were drizzled with chili oil and showered with thin, delicate slivers of green onion and ginger. And the combination stir-fried vegetables were similarly cut by a master with a cleaver - the lotus root, celery, etc. were all beautifully cut and perfectly sauteed, with a nice crispness. 

Also, we had the jian-bing, like a Beijing street pancake, but thought the batter was a little too salty on this one, wouldn't order again. Was interesting to try, as it was made of buckwheat (I think, judging from the speckled flour) but wasn't a huge fan. Would rather eat more noodles or dumplings! 

And, Yao Ming ate here!
author: Annie M.

description: Their food was so nasty me my husband went and ate and plus they don't have that much variety to pick the lady that was serving us she is so lazy she should not be working we will not be coming back to this restaurant and guess what they take out the tips right away that is not right they don't even ask you or tell you the tip was $5.98 crazy shit
author: Erlie I.

description:
To be really honest, there are not too many good restaurants where I live - Mission Terrace. I generally venture away from my living quarters for an enjoyable "food experience". Since my friend that I had met up tonight preferred not to go too from home (she also lives in the Mission Terrace), I decided on Beijing Restaurant because it is in my bookmarks, I have never dined there, and it is within close proximity.

The Good:
1) Clean
2) Simple decor embellished with Peking accessories
3) Friendly staff
4) Fast service
5) Menu is clearly labeled and organized
6) Tea offering is tasty
7) Food is not great tasting (i've had better), but is good overall

*We ordered Beef with Broccoli (my friends #1 go to at any Chinese restaurant), Pan Fried Pot Stickers/Dumplings, Egg Flower Soup (with pork and corn), and Special Steamed Meat Balls.

* I Want to try all their dumplings in the future

Now for the Bad:
1)Restaurant is a bit small, luckily we came before it got packed with loud chatter, and luckily we weren't rushed to get the check since there were still open tables.
2)For a restaurant that does infact accept "credit cards", it fails to list which "plastic" types they offer. I suppose that might be an option YELP could add.

*I am a bit appauled, because I went in hoping to use my everday go to - I am sorry, but I love American Express, and it is upsetting when my AMEX card is not accepted at any given business. I handed my card to the waitress, and without even looking at the card type she takes it to the register. Five minutes later she comes back and said that she tried to use my card and just realized that Beijing Restaurant does not accept AMEX. So okay, I asked if they accept DISCOVER - apparently, that is not accepted either..... Anyways, they only accept VISA and MASTERCARD, so I payed with my Debit card. I think businesses should accept all types of credit cards!

Overall, I would give Beijing Restaurant 4 stars, but based on the fact that they only accept two types of plastic cards - only 3 stars.

[Only accepts VISA & MASTERCARD]
author: Alex C.

description:
Mmm...one of my favorite places to go when i want authentic Northern style Chinese food! The dishes are similar to how my bf's mom makes it. & boy do I love her cooking.

Coming here is a treat since it's a little more pricey compared to what you'd expect to pay for at other Chinese restaurants with similar dishes. However, I think it's more quality than quantity here, which is more important to me (ain't settling for less now that I'm past those college student days!). I never feel like I've had an overdose of grease, calories, or possible msg in my system after meals from here.

The interior isn't much to look at - one big room for the dining area right when you walk in. The decorations are tacky, but I don't expect much here. Getting through the entrance is weird since they put some kind of freezer curtain for you to fight through right after you open the front door. Seriously, I don't understand that. And service is meh - hit or miss in good customer service.

Although, what's cool is that Yao Ming has been here so they have a few pictures of him on the wall.

Food:
+ Steam meat balls ($10.95) - 4 big meatballs with sauce served on a bed of lettuce. Perfect with rice!
+ Boiled seafood and vegetables in a warm pot ($11.95) - refreshing. Plenty of variety and served in generous portions. Good for 2-3 people.
+ Green onion pancake ($7.95) - addicted to these. So crispy and a good sub for rice.
- Lamb skewers ($6) - 4 pcs. Decent, albeit dry so I wouldn't order this one again.

Overall: For quality Chinese food (Northern style), this is a place to hit up. Take note: it's a $$ Chinese restaurant. They take card as well!
author: Loriel L.

description:
Although the 40th/Irving location opened up about a month ago in Outer Sunset, we thought to come to the orig. which opened up 2 years back, in order to shop at Manila Oriental afterward. 

Awesome food---layering of flavors and spicy notes really very tasty.

One order lamb sa guo (clear broth soup served in an open tureen, kept warm with flame below. with special pickled cabbage which rounds out the overall flavor with a smooth, slightly sour kick)

One order cumin lamb--crispy sautee/wok flavor with tons of cumin and a spicy bite to it.

Hong xiao niu rou mian---braised brisket in a darker broth....noodles (thick-cut) were sooo yummy

Jing dong rou bing--pork-stuffed meat pie ensconced in a very skillfully crafted thin layer of dough and layered throughout (3, i think) and then pan-fried. Perfection!!!

Total for meal $40. Bargain

PS There is a parking lot to the place...if coming from 280, drive past it and then do a 180 in order to spot it. Place fills up quickly, although we arrived just before the throngs came for a warm, tasty lunch.
author: Jana C.

description:
Me: "Been to any good restaurants lately?"
J: "Have you tried Beijing Restaurant on Alemany and Ocean?"
Me: "Err, Chinese food in The Mission?" *scratches head* 
J: "But, Yao Ming eats there!"
Me: "SOLD!"

When I went to see my friend and hairdresser, he told me about this gem in The Mission. At first, I was iffy b/c who eats Chinese food in The Mission?!?!  But, if it's good enough for Yao Ming, it's good enough for me!

My friend and I came here for dinner on Sunday, August 29th at 5:15ish. As you can tell, I'm a bit behind on my reviews. :X

Beijing is quite small with several tables to accommodate a party of four, and then a large rectangular table in the back to accommodate 16. Since we came early enough, we were promptly seated. 

FOOD:
BR serves up Northern Chinese Cuisine meaning you will find dishes with Szechuan and Shanghai influences that many other Chinese restaurants in the city won't have.  

If you're on a diet, make sure to ask how the dishes are cooked b/c some of the dishes are fried when I thought it would be braised or steamed.

*Sizzling Seafood Rice Soup ($5.95): YUM! The soup was very comforting; the broth was rich and flavorful as opposed to being salty. The scallops, calamari, and shrimp were fresh, sweet, and tender. The sizzling rice is like rice crispies that are placed on the soup upon serving which give it a nice texture contrast.

*Cumin Lamb ($9.95): VERY GOOD! The lamb was stir fried to a perfect tenderness and wasn't too gamey. The cumin flavor was very prominent which was slightly bitter and nutty, while the peppercorns added a strong kick.

*Ground Bean Sheet w/ Pork ($7.95):YUM! This is basically a rendition of chow fun (wet). The bean sheets are like clear chow fun noodles which were tender w/ a bite. The pork was tender and flavorful and the bean sprouts added a nice fresh crisp to the dish.

*House Special Steamed Meatball ($9.95): GOOD! These meatballs are basically lion head meatballs which is a hearty comfort food for me. The fist-sized meatballs were soft, tender, full of flavor; salty, savory, and sweet from the white/black pepper, soy, ginger, and scallions.
 
*Egg Surface Tofu ($8.95): OK. I thought the tofu would be steamed or braised since it would be topped w/ an egg white sauce. However, it was fried. Aside from the misunderstanding, the tofu was soft, tender and the runny egg white sauce added creaminess to the tofu.

SERVICE:
Efficient and prompt, however, there was a slight language barrier. My friend can't eat fish and the Sizzling Rice Soup came w/ fish, so it took some explaining and hand gestures to the waiters. 

Overall Beijing is the real deal when it comes to Northern Chinese Cuisine. All the dishes are authentically cooked and as opposed to using salt or MSG, they utilize spices to produce flavorful dishes that will tingle your taste buds!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Very very authentic beijing style food. Peking duck is a must try, also egg pancake, some of the dishes are hard to find in the bay area. Service is a ok, the server talks too much and likes to joke with you, some might find funny but I think it is kind of annoying.
author: William C.

description: We had been here several times in the past few years, and the quality of the food has slowly decreased overtime. For one, the dish is getting smaller, more oily, and less fresh. I think this is a reflection of fewer customers coming here. If you live around the area, and you want a quick fix of Chinese food, then you could come here. But just remember what typical Chinese cheap buffet taste like, set your expectation, then you are ready.
author: Sandie Y.

description: some of the worst customer service i've ever experienced, not to mention their food is mediocre at best. it's very clear whoever owns this place stopped caring about the quality of their food and ingredients a long time ago. they are EXTREMELY stingy with the meat in their dishes. i've gotten several entrees where you would have to look for the meat to find it. i just don't understand the appeal of this place. i feel like it was much better a few years ago, as shown by all the pictures in the restaurant. it's sad because i would have loved to experience their food when it was good.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Surprisingly BAD. Food material is not good-quality, service is sub-par, and the carpet smelled so bad that you just cannot ignore upon entering.

We ordered cumin lamb (dry but ok, 3.5/5), onion pancake (very little union, plain; 3/5), boiled spicy beef (very few beef if they are actually beef... 2.5/5), and eggplant (sweet with a thick layer of sauce; 2.5/5). On top of the food, service is classic low quality. 

CASH ONLY as well... Couldn't be worse.
author: Zhihua D.

description:
Let me tell you about an ongoing experience I have. Here is a typical take out conversation via phone:

Them: *Uttering Chinese*..."go ahead"
Me: Hi, I'd like to place an order for takeout.
Them: Ok. Go.
(I then place my order)
Them: Ok. Bye.

They never tell me how much my order totals or when it will be ready. If I don't pick it up within 20 minutes, I get a phone call in a loud voice telling me I need to pick it now. I walk in and they utter to me "I've been waiting for you for a while. You need to pick up your orders quicker." I want to tell them they should specify this rather than blame me, but they're not worth my time and I would hit a new low to be arguing with a takeout chinese place.

Also, 20 minutes is a long time? Seriously?! 

Long story short, I only go here because I live across the street and its extremely convenient/the food is decent. The people are absolutely terrible though and the inside/outside looks like a sewer system.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Genuine Chinese according to my father who is not Chinese and has never been to china but does have a friend who wrote a Chinese cookbook 30 years ago. Best scallion pancakes. Love everything hot and sour. Everything's good really.
author: S Blair P.

description:
For all the negative ratings down there, I say they are honest. I would give this restaurant negative stars if I can.

The food is ok, but the customer service is TERRIBLE. I have never EVER been to a restaurant that is so disrespectful to its customers. I have literally seen them picking up utensil from the floor and DIRECTLY put it on one of the tables. Yes, customers, you don't even know what you are putting into your mouth.

The other time I ordered something for delivery, the experience didn't get any better. When I gave them the delivery address, the person on the phone just couldn't get the name of the address. I literally spent 10 minutes spelling out NELSON RISING LN. Literally. 

OK. I understand they are not native speakers so I went on with my utter patience. I said "I want No.x, blah blah blah; No.y, blah blah blah." While I try to be nice and make things go smooth, it made the guy on the phone impatient (WTF?). Him: "Don't say the numbers." Then I gave them my credit card number, the guy went: "If you're not pausing every four numbers I'm not writing it down". And no, he didn't say it in a suggestive manner, but really made me feel he was the boss and he's telling me I'm not doing the right thing. I am utterly offended.

To the staff in this restaurant, there is a saying that customers are always right. You don't get to dictate how the customers make order. And If you don't get something the customer said, APOLOGIZE, say sorry or pardon me. Or I assure you that your place is gonna close down in a few years.

To the fellow customers, run if you don't want to be bullied by these rude people. There are tons of nicer restaurants out there.
author: Eve S.

description:
Absolutely fantastic delivery spot, not in love with the eat-in experience. Super fast with delivery and the people are nice.

Took a friend here who is from north China and he said the sliced meats are super authentic.

Pine nut shrimp, spicy garlic eggplant are two things we always get, and then the dim sum menu is pretty tasty too. I also like the ground bean sheet noodles, great for when you are craving noodles but trying to do low carb :)
author: Kayla B.

description:
When my chowmein arrived, my delivery guy looked up expectantly. "No tip for me?" he said. "I tipped on the card when I ordered from eat24," I said, caught off guard. "I don't get that card tip. I need cash tip." he replied. I looked around uneasily and thought about whether or not I had cash to throw atop the $4 tip I'd already given. "I don't have any cash and I already tipped you." I didn't know what else to tell him and he just stood there staring at me. I felt uneasy, like maybe he'd come later and take what is rightfully his. (Cause I'm dramatic AF)

"Okay," he finally said after a 10 second staring contest that felt like 10 minutes, "Next time, I know. I know, next time." and then he left. I stood at the door watching his car go off, unsure if he meant he'll beat me up next time, I'll tip him more next time or was he just repeating what people who don't tip say? (again, he wasn't scary, I'm just ridic) I felt bad. I felt indicted. I felt like I needed to overtip now to compensate for all the people who DON'T tip him. I felt responsible.

I called the restaurant and spoke to someone who said that they don't take credit card tips, only cash. "Then who got my $4 tip?" I really wanted to know. The man on the phone told me I can come in and tip Joe (the delivery guy) in person, if I wanted him to get a tip, but that was it.  I hung up, no longer dejected and mainly just over it all.

Then I opened my hot, yummy looking noodles, took a big bite and stared at the bland, flavorless meal in front of me. What an illusion. How can you have so many yummy things in your chowmein and manage to render it flavorless? I ate 4 bites and gave up.

Loss all around.
author: Donna J.

description:
tip: siu long bao not really the soupy dumplings you'd come to expect. Rather, it's just a thicker skin version of it with no soup inside.  

The stir fried kidneys dish was very tasty.  scallion pancake was bland at times.  skewers are just okay.  pot stickers were good but not great

overall a good restaurant but nothing sticks out that really warrants another visit in this part of town.
author: Jacky K C.

description:
*Sigh*

I'm a niu rou mian (beef noodle soup) connoisseur. I'm just going to say it right now. No false modesty, no fake humility. I grew up with the stuff, it's my version of comfort food, I've studied its history, creation and technique extensively, and I make it myself. I've had beef noodle soup cooked by master Taiwanese chefs where the noodles are the definition of al dente ("kiu kiu" in Mandarin) because they're completely handmade, the beef and broth are stewed for an entire day and the bok choy (my preference over spinach) is just the right amount of crisp. I wasn't expecting anything like that from Beijing Restaurant, but I was expecting a certain level of quality for a restaurant purporting to offer Northern Chinese cuisine.

The beef noodle soup here sucks. Don't get it. It's flavorless, oily beyond description and just plain gross. The beef is actually stewed quite nicely and very tender, but its good qualities are lost in a badly seasoned broth accompanied by overcooked, mushy bok choy (of which they only give a couple). The best thing I can say about their beef noodle soup is it's still miles better than that atrocious mess at Kingdom of Dumpling.

The Beef with Green Onions is much better and gives me hope that Beijing Restaurant kind of knows what it's doing. In this dish, the beef was tender and perfectly flavored without being overwhelmed by all the green onions. Served simply over a bed of fragrant, jasmine long-grain rice, it's a simple, tasty meal for those days when you don't want to deal with anything fancy.

I do plan on trying Beijing Restaurant again and ordering other dishes that they might be better at, so this review might get updated with a higher rating. But for now, I'll cross this place off as yet another beef noodle soup disappointment.
author: Josephine L.

description: Always a good meal, flavorful and affordable. Tonight we had Salt & Pepper Pork / Sesame Chicken with Broccoli. .
author: Robert L.

description:
When you approach this restaurant, it looks like some dingy little shack. And then once you push through the plastic curtain that covers the front door after you open it... you realize you are indeed in a dingy little shack. The restaurant is pretty small, but they can accommodate large groups of 10 because of the large banquet tables.

FOOD: CHEAP, COMFORTING AND DELICIOUS. I recommend the beef noodle soup (veggies, beef, spicy broth and udon type noodles), Cumin Lamb (My favorite, spicy and flavorful. Tender not overcooked lamb, that didn't taste gamey), Chinese Burger (ground meat, green onions in a "bao" type bun). Dinner here for a group of 10 getting at least 8 dishes was somewhere in the $12-$15 neighborhood. 

STAFF: RUDE RUDE RUDE. I did not like the service I got at all. Overall, when going to a restaurant you should not feel bad for asking for: 1.) more bowls to eat the food you are paying for or 2.) Water to Drink. If you can stomach the service, then it is okay. 

Logistics:
PARKING: Street parking available in the surrounding neighborhood. Be careful in the dark alleys at night

Overall, I wouldn't come back to this little shack. The food is worth coming for, but the environment and staff would keep me away. The place felt really dirty and I had a fear of a cockroach in my food!
author: Christine B.

description:
I'm really surprised this place has such high ratings. Maybe our service was bad because we had a party of over 20. But they were definitely overwhelmed and therefore, had very poor customer service. We had to ask for water over 5 times to different waiters, and get out of our seats to do so, because the waiters were too scared to make eye contact with us. Or even come near our table. 

First, they failed to give us white rice, after many attempts of asking. Then they messed up on an order of Chicken Chow Mein twice. First they forgot to put our order in after 30 minutes of waiting. Then they brought over combination chowmein in stead of chicken chow mein. After we told them that was wrong, Shrimp Chow Mein appeared on their table.. My friends were starving so they didnt care anymore and just thought they should just eat it. 

Until we realized we would probably get charged more for it. Indeed I was right. I told them the problem, and they seemed to just shrug it off and say it would get fixed. But we were sick of waiting, and said we just want our food, but we dont want to be charged for something we didn't order. So either give us the right food, or charge us for what we ordered, but don't try to give us a more expensive dish and force us to pay for it. The second we brought money into the issue. their Chicken Chow Mein appeared in five minutes. -__-; 

Never going back.
author: Cindy C.

description: Beijing restaurant is the best Chinese restaurant north of Koi Palace in Daly City.
author: John P.

description:
Food is pretty decent Beijing-style.

Actually it's very good, I'm just not a huge fan of the Beijing-style xiaolongbao, and the dan dan noodle (was that it?)'s sauce was waaay too salty.

They actually manage to have parking, they can handle a decent sized group, and even if the kitchen is a smidgen slow (maybe I was just impatient?) the price is right for what amounts to a fairly authentic Chinese dive.

I suspect it's a 4-star place, but for the reasons above, it just didn't work for me. They've got a generous menu, I clearly need to explore more of it before passing a more comprehensive judgement.
author: Brian W.

description:
Beijing Restaurant serves legit, Northern Chinese cuisine. It doesn't make many accommodations for people expecting American-Chinese food, or Southern Chinese food. 

The cumin lamb is excellent. Flavorful and lots of cumin. It normally comes very spicy but you can request without spice. The beef pancake is tasty, but be forewarned it's also a grease bomb. The pea shoots are delicious: flavorful and not too oily or overcooked. They may have been the highlight of our meal.

The house noodles with special sauce was the only major letdown. The noodles were gummy and the sauce didn't have a good flavor.

As you'd probably expect, the restaurant decor is nonexistent. The place has a bit of a funky odor to it, too. Not at all surprising that it nearly failed its last health inspection.
author: David C.

description: The sour cabbage and fish soup was delicious.  I tried the veggie pancake too and it was fresh and satisfying.  On a weeknight the place filled up quickly with families and couples, all Asian.  The service was good and the restaurant was very clean.  I will be back!
author: J E.

description:
Love this place. It's near my house, it's affordable, it's got tasty food that gets made quick. And there's no crazy line. 

The eggplant with brown sauce or house sauce is awesome. Get it. The Chinese "hamburgers" with meat and chives inside are really good appetizers. Hard to choose between that and the beef pancake, which is deliciously crispy (but really meant to be shared, unlike the hamburgers).

I also really liked the soup with sliced fish and preserved vegetables in a warm pot. Wasn't expecting it to be sour (due to the veggies), but it was actually really good. The white fish was super soft and tender.

Service was fine for me. Everyone is pretty friendly.
author: Youngshim H.

description:
Peking duck is great!
The place is great, very Beijing flavor.
You should really try the tea In here. 一定要吃啊，必须得来啊。店面很好啊，有很多名人过来吃。
author: Yang R.

description:
Napa cabbage and tofu hot pot - loved it, though I'm biased as I've always loved this soup. Has vermicelli

Pork with pancake slices (Beijing chao bing) - not too bad though I wish it had less liquid, a solid choice but not good enough for me to get again

Steamed meatballs - they need to update the pic because the meatballs are like 2x bigger than it looks in the pic. Solid taste but same as above, would rather try something else

Rou jia mo (hamburger) - no good, meat not enough fat and bun too hard / dry, stay away 

Ma la beef tripe - decent though could use more salt, a decent choice

Beijing combination vegetables - surprisingly decent and not oily like every other Chinese vegetable dish, solid choice

Everything was solid except the hamburger, with the hot pot being the winner. Would love to come back to this authentic place
author: Mark D.

description:
Even though the location of this restaurant is fairly close to my home I would have not found it so soon had it not been for Yelp.  I first tried some menu items from this restaurant back in June, and I've become a regular customer since, but only recently have I actually sat inside the restaurant to eat.

The restaurant space is fairly small.  Hundreds of photographs adorn the walls and if you've read some of the other reviews you'll probably already know that basketball star Yao Ming is featured on several of them.  The service is excellent, and honestly, when was the last time you heard that about a casual, inexpensive Chinese restaurant in the City?  They have their own parking lot too, and they deliver to the neighborhood.  They even deliver for free if your food total hits the $15 minimum.

I've stuck to the House Specials, the hand pulled noodles and the Beijing dim sum for the most part.  I think the only dish I've ordered not listed under those three categories was a beef chow fun, and I've had that at least three times.  Here are some of the items I've tried when I've dined at the restaurant.

House Special Steamed Baozi (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/OagR2JyL-nSm1oBYQ1O1hw/l) and (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ljnVUENOs0WR-U4YELdChw/l) - These are little steamed buns with a lean pork and chopped Chinese greens filling.  They're not soupy like xiao lung baos, and the outer bun is quite thin.  These are quite good but only when they're hot.

Three Flavor Dumplings (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/_lbwwg7dJWwJl_UEmiHz2A/l) and (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/5LgcTqh7dnz3525Tk5cuuw/l) - These are my favorite steamed dumplings here.  They're packed with a juicy mixture of ground pork, ground chicken, shrimp and chopped chives.

Beef Stew Noodle Soup (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/a-IzRHuhtOzz4FRrEUV1Pg/l) - I love their hand pulled noodles which are less doughy than some and always seems to have the exact same chewy consistency and texture.  The beef stew has a good mix of meaty pieces, pieces with tendons and tender Shanghai bok choy.  I'm not a big fan of the dark brown broth though because I think it lacks depth.

Preserved Vegetable Shredded Pork Noodle Soup (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/qkiy-6GpgCJEX8LXLgOB-w/l) - This is easily my favorite of the soup noodles here.  I often have the spicy preserved vegetables with pork over rice at home, so this selection is very homey to me.  The vegetables and pork are stir fried then served on top of the handmade noodles and chicken broth.  I love the little splash of sesame oil to finish the stir fry.  It just taste so good!  The broth in this dish is usually perfectly seasoned for me.

Beef Chow Fun (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/GLnj-MVDPlzLzfgO1q5tTw/l) - I learned about good wok hay at a very young age.  Wok hay in Cantonese often refers to foods cooked perfectly in a wok with a nice seared flavor locked into the ingredients.  The fried beef in Beijing's beef chow fun has a beautiful crust on nearly each piece of meat sizzled to near perfection.  They go really easy on the bean sprouts and the onions too meaning I get more chewy rice noodles than I do inexpensive fillers.

House Special Hot Chicken Wings (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/EU38hA8fVl4pLn1yXJ2IgQ/l) - These crispy fried chicken wings are very good with a nice outer crust and juicy meat on the inside.  Mixed in a saute of green onion, white onion, cilantro and dry red chiles the flavor had absolutely no spicyness to it however.  Perhaps had they broken the meat of the chiles that would have helped.  If you want good chicken wings these are very good.  If you want good, spicy chicken wings then these are definitely disappointing.

Overall I'd give a 4.5, but for hand-pulled noodles and flavorful dumplings delivered to my front door I've got nothing but 5 star love for Beijing Restaurant.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: This place is excellent everything was good besides the none speaking English workers it was all perfect especially the garlic shrimp make to. Perfection
author: Chi G.

description: Decent, but expensive for the price given. There's a more affordable option in Sunset that has same dishes. I remember ordering the green onion pancakes, cucumbers in chili oil, lamb in cumin, and chive dumplings? I guess I don't like repeating myself, but the name of this place says it all. Beijing Restaurant will specialize more in Northern Chinese food so basically if you are ordering the typical American Chinese food or something that's not native to the region, don't expect the dish to be the best.
author: Wesley K.

description:
It is really freaking hard to make my parents happy at a Chinese restaurant. My Dad hates Dimsum or anything Cantonese, he is one hardcore Northerner. I'm trying hard to convince them that there is decent Chinese food in California outside of Queens.

Parking in small lot out front is tight but at least its there! The place was packed with mostly Asians - promising. The bathroom was a little scary, ok lets be honest here, it was a lot scary. The food bits that came on the spoons they brought us and the questionable table wipe down - terrifying. Service was not nearly as bad as people say, it was actually pretty reasonable considering how busy they were. It's impressive how they juggle all the take out orders and a packed restaurant from such cramped quarters.

The food was authentic and tasty:
- Cumin lamb - Really good, not at all gamey, one of the only lamb dishes that I've been able to handle ever. Not bad as leftovers either.
- Pork and pickled vegetable clay pot - Perfect - Exactly as it should taste
- Shrimp & pine nuts - OK, not exactly authentic, but the shrimp was super tender. Better if you peel off the batter.

$15/person - Between the cheap prices and the authentic food, Dad was happy, no easy feat there.
author: Snuffles B.

description:
We had such high hopes for this place since they have a "4 star" rating on Yelp. Their delivery service took over an hour. Then the food gets here & it's very bland & Luke warm. The Mongolian beef had little to no beef! The chicken in the dishes we ordered had no flavor. Super small portions too for the cost!!! 

We were soooo disappointed & will never order from here again!
author: Tifanie W.

description:
I have been going to this place for about three years. I like their foo but their customer service could be better. Sometimes when you call and place an order they can be very RUDE, and since their accent is SO STRONG, it is also hard to understand them and viceversa. If you have any experience with customer service, it is absolutely not necessary to be RUDE on the phone by saying: W-H-E-R-E I-S. Y-O-U-R  A-D-D-R-E-S-S? Like if I was retarded.
Thank you for delivering, but at this point I rather try some other place, where they actually take care of people.
author: Moni T.

description: Decided to give them a chance, hoping the food was good. I was mistaken. Food was bland, I stopped eating after 2 bites. Will not be ordering from them again. Driver got lost he was on the wrong block.
author: Patricia G.

description: Food isn't that great anymore and also the service is horrible. The waiter was very rude and told me sit down and wouldn't want to give me my change back
author: Bob B.

description:
The most real chinese place ever.

They A had food in less than 10 minutes, which is nice, and the inside is really nice.

I've driven by this place like 100 times and decided to go get some take out with my girlfriend, and we both came to the conclusion that it was really good. The person at the station recommended the basil chicken which was very yumzzzzzzz.

yummy.

This is not the most gourmet chinese food ever, but it's still very good for the price.
author: John C.

description:
I've eaten at/from Beijing a few times now. I have never gotten food poisoning from Beijing, so on the scale of good Chinese places, this place ranks high for me.

The salt and pepper tofu is awesome. I don't like tofu, but this was so good. We also had some pork variation, and it was just too sweet, as were the meatballs. The mongolian beef, however, was great. Stay away from the dumplings, though. No bueno.

The good: decent food.
The bad: all of our dishes came in rapid succession, and we ran out of table space. Eat up, eat quickly.
